results.title: The Man from Snowy River II
results.brief_description: Jim Craig has been away on the plains droving and gathering a large mob of horses to breed in his high country. Now he has returned to claim his heritage and the woman he loves. “The Man From Snowy River II” continues the legend and brings to life a man whose simple strength will endure forever.

results.title: A Walk in the Sun
results.brief_description: Powerful and bold in its story, ‘A Walk in the Sun’ is unforgettable in its drama. The masterful director of “All Quiet on the Western Front” has again captured the deepest emotions of men at war.

results.title: The Snows of Kilimanjaro
results.creator_credit: Henry King, Darryl F. Zanuck and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: A hunter lies wounded in Africa and while waiting for help looks back over his life and loves. Hollywood version of a portable Hemingway, with reminiscences of several novels stirred into a lush and sprawling mix of action and romance, open spaces and smart salons. A big popular star film of its time. Starring Gregory Peck, Susan Hayward and Ava Gardner.

results.title: The Perils of Pauline
results.creator_credit: George Marshall, Sol Siegel and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Fabricated biography of silent serial queen, Pearl White. A frantic re-creation of old time Hollywood, with plenty of slapstick chases. Stars Betty Hutton, Billy De Wolfe, William Demarest, Constance Collier and Frank Faylen. Based on the story by P.J. Wolfson, with credit to Charles W. Goddard who wrote the original serial.

results.title: He walked by night
results.creator_credit: Alfred L Werker and Robert T Kane
results.brief_description: In the suspenseful tradition of “The Naked City”, and drawn from the documented files of L.A.P.D. Homicide files, “He Walked by Night” is a first class suspense thriller about a desperate burglar who turns into a cop killer and is hounded down by the police. Richard Basehart is brilliant as the fearless fugitive.

results.title: The Third man
results.creator_credit: Carol Reed and London Film Productions
results.brief_description: A lucky combination of talents gave this romantic thriller, set in war-torn Vienna, an almost poetic quality and an excitement which has kept it vivid. The photogenic ruins provided a suitable background for the four star actors: Joseph Cotton, Valli, Trevor Howard and Orson Welles. Graham Greene wrote a bitter, well-timed script adapted from his own novel, Robert Krasker lovingly photographed and Carol Reed directed every scene with the surest of touches and then there was the insistent zither music by Anton Karas.

results.title: The Stranger
results.brief_description: An escaped Nazi criminal marries an American woman and settles in a Connecticut village. A highly convincing melodrama - enhanced by directorial touches, splendid photography and no-holds barred climax, involving a church clock.

results.title: I Cover the Waterfront
results.brief_description: A reporter uses a girl’s friendship to expose her father’s smuggling activities. “I Cover the Waterfront” is a tough and daring melodrama about organised crime and the brave men who try to expose it. Stars Claudette Colbert. Rated: G

results.title: Scarlet Street
results.creator_credit: Fritz Lang, Walter Wanger and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Lang’s darkest American film is a twisted moral tale that benefits from Edward G Robinson’s fine performance as a company man who is driven to embezzlement as a result of his passion for a scheming vixen. Lang’s impeccable shadowed visions and the air of slovenly decadence with which he surrounds the woman and her secret lover, plus the raw force of the bitter ending, set this apart from the subsequent tales of seduction by a femme fatale. Also stars Joan Bennett and Dan Durea. Based on the play La chienne by George de la Fouchardiere and previously filmed by Jean Renoir.

results.title: You're Telling Me
results.brief_description: Includes excerpts from “The Bank Dick” this is WC Fields at his best. Portraying small town inventor Sam Bisbee whose works (eg. a keyhole finder for drunks) have brought him only poverty. His daughter is in love with the son of the town snob. Events conspire to ruin his bullet-proof tire just as success seems near. Another of his inventions prohibits him from committing suicide, so Sam decides to go on living.
